captions.text:
MALE SPEAKER: So when you look
down at that then, that's like
an X.
MATT PARKER: It is.

It's one of my ex-favorite
numbers.

For a while, my favorite
number was 3,435.

And I say for a while, because
I don't think a favorite

number -- you don't commit
to a favorite number
for life, to be honest.

Very few things that I'll have a
static opinion on what is my

favorite, other than
my girlfriend.

Whereas 3,435 for a
while there was
one of my top numbers.
I'll show you why.

And actually, it probably had a
bit of a record run as being
my favorite number.

3,435, it's called a
Munchausen number.

And what you do for a Munchausen
number is you raise

each of the digits to the
power of that digit.

So 3 to the 3 plus 4 to
the 4 plus 3 to the 3
plus 5 to the 5.

And if you then add 3 to the 3
plus 4 to the 4 plus 3 to the

3, plus 5 to the 5,
it equals 3,435.
It equals itself.

It's a bit like a narcissistic
number, which I'm sure people
will be talking about.

Except this time, each number
is obsessed with itself.

In fact, the Munchausen
it's named after was a
narcissistic character.

And so it's a very, very
narcissistic number.

And what's even better about
it is it's the only one.

In base 10, this is
the only number
which has that property.

Well, it was the only number
that has that property.

If you look up online, whenever
you talk about the

Munchausen number and you talk
about 3,435, someone will come

along and say, but what about
438,579,088, huh?
What about that?

MALE SPEAKER: Yeah, I was
just about to say that.

MATT PARKER: It was on the tip
of your tongue, wasn't it?

Because 4 to the 4 plus 3 to the
3 plus 8 to the 8 plus 5

to the 5 plus 7 to the 7 plus
9 to the 9 plus 0 to the 0

plus 8 to the 8 plus 8 to the
8 equals 438,579,088.

And people are all up in your
grill with what up with this?

And there is a problem
with that.

There's a reason why that makes
me emotional, and I'll
show you why.
It is this bit here--
0 to the 0.

This relies on 0 to
the 0 equaling 0.

And it turns out 0 to the
0 does not equal 0.

Nor does it equal 1,
for that matter.
0 to the 0 is undefined.

There is no value for 0 to the
0, because anything to
the 0 equals 1.

And 0 to the anything
equals 0.

And when both of those things
happen at once, you basically

have a big argument, and people
get very emotional
about this.

If you want to find equally core
numbers, there are things

like 4,155, which equals the
digits at the bottom--

4,155 to the power of the same
digits, but not necessarily in
the same order.

So if you put them up as in 5,
4, 1, 5, that still holds.

But you've got to shuffle the
digits around when you raise
them up the top.

MALE SPEAKER: You mentioned to
me that was your favorite
number for a long time.
MATT PARKER: Yeah.

MALE SPEAKER: It was your
favorite number for possibly a
record time.

MATT PARKER: It must have
been seven or eight
months it was up there.
It was good.
MALE SPEAKER: What happened?
Why did you break up?

MATT PARKER: It was
fun, but it just--
I got bored.
I got bored.

And I went back to the safety
of narcissistic
numbers for a while.

So 371 took over for a
substantial period of time.

And then I wanted to go
back into perfect
numbers for a while.
So 33,550,336 took back over.
And at the moment, it's 764.

But that's because it's
a grafting number.

But this is not the time nor
the place to talk about
grafting numbers.

comments.author: Zachary Mitchell

comments.text:
Xiao, I think that's because of PEMDAS. See, without writing anything, -3^2 
is actually -9, not 9 as you may think. That's because exponents go before 
multiplication. So -3^2 becomes -(3)^2 = -9 instead of (-3)^2. Same with 
-3^0. Instead of (-3)^0 it does -(3)^0. Try putting parenthesis around your 
-3, then do your power. If you want, I can explain why (-3)^0 must equal 1 
if you want though. It's also help you understand why you can't give a 
value to 0^0.
comments.author: Zachary Mitchell

comments.text:
Why is -3^0 equivalent to -3/-3? I think your right because online sources 
corroborate your statement, but when i enter -1^0 in my calculator or 
wolfram i get -1.
comments.author: Xiao Long Guan

comments.text:
+Xiao Long Guan Sorry, but negative numbers to the 0 are positive 1. (-3)^0 
is 1 because -3/-3 = 1. It's also not a limit. All numbers (except for 0) 
to the power of 0 is 1. This is true even for complex (or erroneously 
called imaginary) numbers. You don't 'approach' 1 as x 'approaches' 0. All 
values of x, except for 0, have a y-value of 1. I'm not quite sure why 
you're talking about limits.
comments.author: Zachary Mitchell

comments.text:
+p0gr Say Y=x^0. we want to find the limit as x approaches 0. All positive 
values of x equal one and they approach the value 1. All negative values of 
x equal -1 and therefore approach -1. Because the limit as x approaches 
zero differs depending depending on if you are coming in from the positive 
or negative side, the value y is undefined.
comments.author: Xiao Long Guan

comments.text:
+Xiao Long Guan you seem to have trouble concentrating, so i give it to you 
set by step:
1. please state clearly the limits you are considering and
2. explain precisely why they should have any influence on the value of 0^0.

fyi: empty product is a product with 0 factors, as in the case of ^0. so no 
multiplication takes place, so the value will be the neutral element of 
multiplication, which is 1.
comments.author: p0gr

comments.text:
Also sorry for sounding aggressive, its just I watch alot of MLG montage 
parodies
comments.author: Xiao Long Guan

comments.text:
i heard of empty products and how they equal 1, but im completely not 
familiar with how. But i think 0^0 is undefined because it approaches 2 
different values, 1 and -1, sort of how tangent approaches infinity and 
negative infinity every 90 degrees and stuff.
comments.author: Xiao Long Guan

comments.text:
+Xiao Long Guan your post proves that you didnt understand mine and you 
need to read up a bit on math. i think everyone except you agrees about 
(-1)^0.

you are thinking about 0^x, but why do would you assume it needs to be 
continuous at 0?

whereas the neutral element of multiplication is and stays 1, nobody will 
deny that.
comments.author: p0gr

comments.text:
+p0gr no, 0^0 does not equal 1. this is because positive numbers to the 
power of zero equals one, and negative numbers to the power of zero equals 
minus one. Therefore in a graph y=x^0, the value of y at x=0 is approaching 
2 different values, 1 coming in from the right, and -1 from the left. 
Therefore, 0^0 has no definite answer and is therefore undefined. REKT
comments.author: Xiao Long Guan

comments.text:
no, it's normal to say 1. 0^0 is the empty product, therefore the neutral 
element of multiplication, i.e. 1.

comments.author: Aaron Bowen

comments.text:
If 0 ^ 0 = 0, then 0 ^ -1 would be 0/0. Likewise, 0 ^ 0 would be (0 ^ (1) 
)/0. Each decrement of the exponent would be dividing once by the base. It 
works for 4, for example, as 4 ^ 1 = (4 ^ 2) /4; (4 ^ 0) = (4 ^ 1) /4. But 
with zero, moving from 0 ^ 1 to 0 ^ 0 would result in a division by zero 
error.﻿
comments.author: Shamak

comments.text:
+UraniuProductions Yes, thank you for informing me about that. It's not 
like I didn't know that, and that I wasn't providing a point in a 
roundabout way as to why "we" don't do this in math.

As for a^-b=1/(a^b), I was using an example based off of how you can expand 
the range of exponents. For example, a^3 would be a*a*a, and a^2 would be 
a*a. Then that means that a^(3-1)=a^2, and that would be shown as 
(a*a*a)/a, which simplifies to a*a. This can be expanded to a^-1, which is 
a^(1-2), or a/(a*a). This simplifies to your 1/a. However, this doesn't 
work with zero, because thinking about it gives quite the nice number of 
contradictions.
comments.author: Aslal

comments.text:
+Aslal Actually, a number to a negative power is simply equal to 1 divided 
by the number to that power. so a^-b=1/(a^b). The fact that you can get a 
logic for the positive part doesn't mean it will work from 0 downwards. We 
have many exceptions in math regarding 0.
comments.author: UraniuProductions

comments.text:
+Aaron Bowen I'd say that you're partially right, depending on what you 
make 0^-1 out to be and if you want to be a criminal.

This rule calls out that any number divided by itself cancels to one. So, 
for example, 4^-1 = 4/(4*4), which one set of fours cancels out, leaving 
you with 1/4.

With zero, however, you get 0^-1=0/(0*0), which is undefined. It could also 
be represented as 0^(1-2), which is the same as 0/(0*0). If you multiply 
the zeroes together, then you get 0/0, which can be whatever you want, 
depending on the angle you approach the origin of the graph with (and with 
what function, the slope of that line, etc.). It can be 1, it can be 
infinity, it can be blue, it can even be the amazing wau.

If, however, you use this property first and cancel out the zeroes (and I'm 
breaking math right now just by dividing zero by zero, but bear with me), 
you can use the same property that I mentioned above to get any number you 
wish. 0^-1=1/0? Sure, that works. 0^-1=24/0? Fine too. 0^-1=cake/0? Yep. 
Taking this into consideration, though, one wouldn't cancel out the zeroes 
because that's a big no-no of math.
comments.author: Aslal

comments.text: 0^-1 would equal 1/0 not 0/0
comments.author: Aaron Bowen

comments.author: Simon S (Squoo38)

comments.author: Mike Waska

comments.text:
I'm thinking that whether you think 0^0 is 1 or undefined probably depends 
on what you do with math most often.

Applied mathematics, like physics, the powers are most often exact numbers 
while the other bit is an approximation to one extent or another.  While 
0^0 might be undefined, in a technically sense, it's more like lim x->0 x^0 
when you're applying math to the real world.  So, if you run into 0^0 for 
an applied math problem you can most likely replace that with 1 and get the 
correct (compared to reality) result.

Also, if you define non-negative integer powers (x^n) as a product series 
from 0 to n of x, then when n=0 there is an empty product which is defined 
as 1.

So, it's useful to think of it as 1 whenever you're dealing with reality.  
However you may run into pissed off mathematicians because it's not 
rigorously defined.﻿
comments.author: kevinpfromnm

comments.text:
0^0 is simple.  Order of operations, we start with Zero to the power of... 
zero to the power of anything is zero.  From an operational standpoint it 
equals zero.  The problem comes in when people learn maths from a 'here are 
some rules to follow' standpoint instead of having intuitive mathematical 
operation in their head.  Similarly the tricks used to multiply by 9's and 
11's instead of functionally doing the operation in your head. 

It basically boils down to two ways of dealing with mathematics and one is 
far more difficult for most people do to, but is operationally correct.

Another way to look at it is Zero to the power of Zero is zero alone or 
nothing at all (null statement).﻿

comments.author: UraniuProductions

comments.text:
With an interpretation of combinatorics it is 1. n^m is the the number of 
lists of length m made from n elements. When n = m = 0, there is one such 
list, the empty list. Similarily this shows that 0^m for m != 0 is zero and 
n^0 = 0. Limits nor order of operation enter into the discussion of 0^0's 
value in whole number arithmetic. It is well defined and is 1.
comments.author: sugarfrosted

comments.text:
Saying 0^0 = 0 by following the order of operations is incorrect. Using 
this logic, 0/0 must be 0 and if this is the case, I could prove to you 
that 0 = 1, which of course is nonsense. The rules of math are not made for 
fun, they're made to make sure everything is done correctly. There are only 
two ways to look at math: the correct way and the incorrect way.

comments.text:
0x0 is 0^2, not 0^1. And regarding n^0=1, consider something like 
(n^a)/(n^b). You can rewrite this as n^(a-b). But what if a=b? Then it's 
n^(a-a)=n^0, but the fractional representation is (n^a)/(n^a) = 1. 
Therefore, n^0 = 1.

comments.text:

comments.author: RSGod CraftRiot

comments.text: At this point I don't see how this is related to 1^1 + 0 = 1.
comments.author: Glader

comments.text:
Sorry, I made a wrong statement there, everything I said was a wrong 
statement, anyways, ironically, you're doing an x^x + y^y... = z pattern 
which I told you not to.
comments.author: RSGod CraftRiot

comments.text:
No it's not like saying that at all. A Munchausen number must be a sum of 
it's digit with each digit raised to that digit. 1^1 is not a sum. 1^1 + 0 
is a sum BUT for it to satisfy the criteria it MUST be 1^1 + 0^0 and that 
is undefined. It is literally in the video, they talk about a certain case 
of that. This has nothing to do with x^2 + y^2 = x. It has to do with the 
criteria being fulfilled for it to be a Munchausen number.
comments.author: Glader

comments.text:
@Andrew, that's like saying that 4+9 = undefined because it follows the 
pattern of x^2 + y^2 .. = x
comments.author: RSGod CraftRiot

comments.text: Yes, I agree with undefined more than 1.
comments.author: RSGod CraftRiot

comments.text: No. Equations do not work that way.
comments.author: Wolfgang Amadeus

comments.text:
1^1 + 0^0 = 2 is an expression that can't fully be evaluated because 0^0 is 
undefined.
comments.author: Glader

comments.text:
It still doesn't fit the criteria specifically. It is not the sum of each 
individual digit raised to itself. Sure you can arbitrarily add a 0 but it 
now is no longer a sum of quantities of which are raised to a power of 
themselves. Sorry. Unless of course you can solve 0^0=x for me real quick.
comments.author: Glader

comments.text:
My favorite number is 390'625. Reasoning is pretty simple. 5^2 = 25, which 
has 5 as one of it's digits. 25^2 = 625, which has 25 as digits in the same 
order. 625^2 = 390'625, which has the same property as 25 in 625. 
Unfortunately, 390'625^2 = 150'587'890'625, which no longer really fits the 
pattern. Second favorite is 169, because it's 13^2 and I like 13. I have 
exactly 169 facebook friends at all times.
comments.author: Inspired Noob
